event: Fed announces TAFF.  It supplied short-term credit to banks with sub-prime mortgages.
The rate of foreclosure filings in December 2007 were 97 percent higher than in December 2006.
The Economic Stimulus Act of 2008
Federal Reserve held the first emergency weekend meeting in 30 years to try to save the investment bank,  Bear Stearns.
Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae Bailout.
Lehman Brothers Bankruptcy Triggered Global Recession.
Fed Nationalized the American International Group.
$700 Billion Bailout. On October 3, the Senate passed the
Credit Markets Froze.
End of Investment Banking. In November, Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley became regular commercial banks
Stock Market Crash. By the end of 2008, the Dow was down 34%, closing at 8,816.62. Other indices performed even worse.
The worst month of the Great Recession sees nearly 800,000 jobs lost; the unemployment rate rises to 7.8%, the highest since June 1992.
A Labor Department report shows that the U.S. economy lost nearly 2 million jobs in the last four months of 2008.
Insurance giant AIG reports nearly $62 billion in losses during the fourth quarter of 2008, and the US government gives it $30 billion more in aid in a new bailout.[22]
A report by the Federal Reserve says that U.S. families lost a record 18% of their wealth in 2008
AIG announces it will pay $450 million in bonuses to top executives despite its central role in the global financial meltdown and despite receiving a $173 billion government bailout.
The unemployment rate hits 9% for the first time since September 1983; it will not drop below 9% again until late 2011.
June – The Great Recession officially ends, but job losses continue through December, though at a smaller magnitude; The unemployment rate hits 9.5% for the first time since August 1983.
The unemployment rate peaks at 10.0%, the highest since June 1983.

Small business lender CITI Group  files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy (reorganization) which likely cancels its obligation to pay back the TARP loan of $2.3 billion that it previously received the U.S. government.
A sweeping US healthcare bill passes the Senate, giving President Barack Obama success on his number one domestic priority.
